Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Safety of General Anesthesia in Pediatric Adenotonsillectomy

Trial_Design.evidence: Conducted as a randomised controlled trial in a tertiary care setting

Participants.evidence: children under 15 years old undergoing adenotonsillectomy. Eligibility criteria emphasized obstructive sleep apnea and other comorbidities

Intervention.evidence: the intervention group received a specific anesthetic protocol, while the control group received standard care

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the safety of general anesthesia in adenotonsillectomy

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of perioperative respiratory events, assessed over a 24-hour postoperative period

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group, recruited between January 2020 and June 2021

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group experienced a significant reduction in respiratory events compared to the control group (mean difference = 5.2 events, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events occurred in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild severity
